data.title: JavaScript heap out of memory when debug
data.body:
VSCode Version: 1.9.1
node: 6.5.0
OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Cannot debug script:
```JS
var buffer = Buffer.alloc(2*1024*1024*1024 - 1); //2GB https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v6.x/docs/api/buffer.html#buffer_buffer_kmaxlength
console.log(buffer.length);
```
But it work nice when run from node.

And crash for small size to (example: Buffer.alloc(1024 * 1024 * 100))

data.title: Hot Exit does not work when the computer blue screens
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15025
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.8|
|indentation-level-movement|kaiwood|1.1.1|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.1|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.7.0|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.9.0|
|rewrap|stkb|1.2.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a folder in VS Code and open some editors
2. Bluescreen (obviously not expecting someone to try this on their dev machine)
3. Reopen VS Code when the PC restarts to find that the last session was not saved

I imagine this would be true if the machine lost power or was hard-reset in such a way that VS Code was unable to clean up after itself or save some state.

Expected behavior:

No matter how VS Code was closed, the working state should be restored when it is started up again. Probably could be solved by saving information about which folder and files are open at the time they are opened, instead of at the time VS Code shuts down.

data.title: markdown-it-named-header custom slugify for non-latin characters
data.body:
Issues: non-latin characters (such as japanese) and Markdown preview anchor #20626

**PROBLEM:**

I want to realize an in-page link by using an anchor in Markdown Preview, but it does not work with non-latin characters.
If the header is written in non-latin characters (such as Japanese), it is judged to be an invalid character, so the value of the id attribute is empty.

data.title: Debug bar is draggable outside window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-08T23:31:51.320Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|output-colorizer|IBM|0.0.10|
|html-css-class-completion|Zignd|1.0.3|
|Handlebars|andrejunges|0.2.0|
|vscode-svgviewer|cssho|1.3.1|
|jshint|dbaeumer|0.10.15|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.6|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.5|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.8|
|tslint|eg2|0.8.1|
|Scala|itryapitsin|0.1.7|
|jscs|ms-vscode|0.1.9|
|better-merge|pprice|0.5.1|

---

The debug bar appears able to fall off the left side of the screen in such a way that it can't be dragged back into the window. Unfortunately, because VSCode appears to remember where the bar was at the end of the previous debug session, stopping and restarting doesn't bring the bar back into view. As a workaround, I had to open developer tools and manually reset the CSS rules on the element to bring it back into view.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start a debugging session. The debug bar should appear where it last was.
2. Click and drag the debug bar off the left side of the window.

![screen shot 2017-02-14 at 4 13 39 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3336359/22955688/576b810e-f2d2-11e6-8b8f-008fbbaabc9c.png)

data.title: non-latin characters (such as japanese) and Markdown preview anchor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-08T23:31:51.320Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0 This issue is recognized as not a problem of vscode itself, but because it is used in Markdown extension. PR: markdown-it-named-header custom slugify for non-latin characters #20628 **PROBLEM:** I want to realize an in-page link by using an anchor in Markdown Preview, but it does not work with non-latin characters. If the header is written in non-latin characters (such as Japanese), it is judged to be an invalid character, so the value of the id attribute is empty. **BACKGROUND:** Markdown-it-named-headers (mdnh) generates an id attribute from Markdown's header element and uses the slug() function provided by [`strings.js`](http://stringjs.com/) to convert the text to valid URL slug. example: ```html # Example Header -->

Example

``` There is a problem with non-latin characters. If the header is written in non-latin characters (such as Japanese), it is judged to be an invalid character, so the value of the id attribute is empty. As a result of investigation, processing of non-latin characters can not be performed correctly. (However, it may be correct in the sense that it deletes a character string that can not be used in the URL.) * [string.js: slugify](http://stringjs.com/#methods/slugify) * [slugify russian (non-english) words #43](https://github.com/jprichardson/string.js/issues/43) * [truncate doesn't work with non-latin characters (Japanese) #201](https://github.com/jprichardson/string.js/issues/201) Sample Markdown: ```markdown * [test](#test) * [さくら](#さくら) * [さくら 桜](#さくら-桜) * [🌸](#🌸) ## test ## さくら ## さくら 桜 ## 🌸 ``` Rendered HTML: ```html
  • test
  • さくら
  • さくら 桜
  • 🌸

    • test

    さくら

    <--- here

    さくら 桜

    <--- here

    🌸

    <--- here ``` In Markdown extension, there is a process of creating an href link from a header when anchor `(#anchor)` is specified and rendering `` tag. In this process, the non-latin characters appear to be encodeURI. I think it is a very good process. Markdown-it-named-headers has an option to define custom slugify. So, when a non-latin character was written in the header, I decided to define its custom slug() function. ```ts .use(mdnh, { slugify: function (header: string) { return encodeURI(header.trim() .toLowerCase() .replace(/[\]\[\!\"\#\$\%\&\'\(\)\*\+\,\.\/\:\;\<\=\>\?\@\\\^\_\{\|\}\~]/g, '') //remove symbol .replace(/\s+/g, '-')) // Replace spaces with hyphens .replace(/\-+$/, ''); // Replace trailing hyphen } }) ``` HTML rendered with custom slugify applied: ```html
  • test
  • さくら
  • さくら 桜
  • 🌸

    • test

    さくら

    さくら 桜

    🌸

    ``` Screenshot: ![anchor](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13635244/22955559/140f66f8-f360-11e6-8cfe-0b6a8680972d.gif) This is the best for me. Please tell me if there is any other better way.

data.title: Autofill for JSDocs
Unaligned surrogate pairs are corrupted at multiples of 50 columns.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.10.0-insider (1d17b45a11d8db22fe95c601f793a3cb9a582ba6, 2017-02-14T09:49:25.026Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15025
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.8|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.1|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.7.0|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.9.0|
|rewrap|stkb|1.2.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enter the following text into a new editor with UTF-8 encoding (the specific encoding of the file may not be important): `𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷𠮷` (these are all the character U+20BB7 encoded in UTF-8 as 0xF0 0xA0 0xAE 0xB7 / UTF-16 as the surrogate pair 0xD842 0xDFB7) 
2. Add a character (like 'a') to the beginning of the line which has only a single UTF-16 code unit [1].
3. Observe that some of the original characters (at offsets which are multiples of 50) are now rendered as � (U+FFFD: REPLACEMENT CHARACTER, used to render unknown characters).
4. Observe that copying a the entire run of text or just a selection including the � glyphs will paste into another line or another editor in VS Code or another program correctly as 𠮷. This seems to only affect the current line.
5. Copy the text from step 1 multiple more times onto the end of the line and you will see the corruption repeat periodically, at every 50th column.

[1] Examples:

- The letter 'a' (ASCII) is encoded as a single byte (or a single UTF-16 char) causes the problem.
- U+0280 LATIN SMALL LETTER CAPITAL "ʀ" [UTF-8: 0xCA 0x80 / UTF-16: 0x0280] causes the problem.
- U+4F60 "你" [UTF-8: 0xE4 0xBD 0xA0 / UTF-16: 0x4F60] causes the problem.
- U+20BB6 "𠮶" [UTF-8: 0xF0 0xA0 0xAE 0xB6 / UTF-16: 0xD842 0xDFB6] DOES NOT cause the problem.

I'm guessing the buffer for each line is encoded as UTF-16 and there's something funny about how unaligned surrogate pairs are handled at offsets which are multiples of 50 and the two halves of the surrogate pair occupy offsets x and y (where x mod 50 = 49; y mod 50 = 0) of the buffer (49, 50; 99, 100; 149, 150; etc.).

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/22954819/7e5d849c-f2cd-11e6-8732-902b0b788dee.png)

data.title: How to setup a development environment to debug an extension that uses local changes to vscode.d.ts?
data.body:
I would like to experiment with some changes to vscode.d.ts (the API exposed to extensions).

In order to test these changes locally, I would like to be able to have an extension FOO such that
1. FOO can consume the new/modified APIs in vscode.d.ts
2. I can set breakpoints in FOO and VS Code for debugging.

In my case FOO=vscode-go (an extension that already exists).

***tl;dr*** what is the recommended setup to accomplish what I want?


Long version...here is what I have attempted...

**Method 1:** Inline vscode-go into `vscode/extensions/vscode-go`.

This requires making quite a few changes in vscode
- Exclude vscode-go from some lint rules in gulpfile.hygine.js
- Add vscode-go to list of extensions in build/npm/postinstall.js
- Update vscode-go's package.json
    - Remove vscode as a dev dependency from vscode-go
    - Remove references to `node ./node_modules/vscode/bin/install`
    - Update compile and watch scripts to look like `gulp compile-extension:vscode-go` and `gulp watch-extension:vscode-go`
- Add a refs.d.ts to point to local version of vscode.d.ts
    ```
    /// <reference path='../../../../src/vs/vscode.d.ts'/>
    /// <reference path='../../../../src/vs/vscode.proposed.d.ts'/> 
    ```
- Extension specific hacking. For vscode-go this involved
    - Updating main entry point due to how extension compilation works
        ```
        -"main": "./out/src/goMain",
        +"main": "./out/goMain",
        ``` 
    - Rewriting some import paths
        ```
        -import { getBinPathFromEnvVar } from '../src/goPath';
       +import { getBinPathFromEnvVar } from './goPath';
        ```
    - Export interfaces that need to be exported
    - Update settings in tsconfig.json

I had this method working for a bit (both debugging and consuming new APIs), but within the last 24 hours debugging has broken twice (I can't seem to step in to function calls once I hit a breakpoint). I was able to "fix" this the first time by trying to re-do my setup (ultimately I am not sure what fixed it), but now that it has broken again (and I am not sure what causes this setup to break), I have so far been unable to fix it my repeating my setup process.

**Method 2:** use --extensionDevelopmentPath

This is something that I have just started trying because it seems less than ideal to need to "inline" extensions into vscode via method 1.

The goal of this method is to use `./scripts/code.sh --extensionDevelopmentPath=/Users/nick/code/vscode-go`.

Steps:
- Update vscode-go's package.json
    - Remove vscode as a dev dependency from vscode-go
    - Remove references to `node ./node_modules/vscode/bin/install`
- Add a refs.d.ts to point to local version of vscode.d.ts
    ```
    /// <reference path='../../../../src/vs/vscode.d.ts'/>
    /// <reference path='../../../../src/vs/vscode.proposed.d.ts'/> 
    ```

Right now I am stuck on trying to get breakpoints to work with this method. Setting a breakpoint in vscode-go requires vscode-go to be a subdirectory of my project.

I tried creating a sandbox directory that contains just vscode and vscode-go. In this directory I have a .vscode/launch.json that looks like this

```
{
    // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible Node.js debug attributes.
    // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
    // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "name": "Attach to Extension Host",
            "protocol": "legacy",
            "port": 5870,
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "outFiles": [
                "/Users/nick/code/sandbox/vscode-clean/out/**/*.js",
                "/Users/nick/code/sandbox/vscode-go/out/**/*.js"
            ]
        }
    ]
}
``` 

The vscode-go extension appears to load, but my breakpoints in vscode-go files don't catch.

data.title: "Unable to open 'Unknown Source'" if StackFrame.source is missing
data.body:
As I understand, `StackFrame.source` in the debug protocol is supposed to be optional (because there might not always be a source location available). However, starting with VSCode 1.9.0, a missing `source` causes the following error (after a pause request response, might happen elsewhere too):

![](http://i.imgur.com/xelzPoE.png)

(btw: same thing with a `source` that is present, but has no `path`)

At first glance, this makes it look like pausing didn't work. However, at a second glance, pausing and resuming still works fine, so it's mostly a cosmetic issue (that still might lead the user to think it's broken).

Here's what our debug adapter ([Haxe Debug][1]) sends:

![](http://i.imgur.com/svdJxnh.png)

This works fine (no error appears) in 1.8.1, which would make this a regression. The issue is still present in the latest Insider's build (1d17b45a11d8db22f).

Other debug adapters seem to have the same issue, as suggested by [this StackOverflow question][2] regarding the same error message with ASP.NET.

Issue #4608 seems somewhat related to this.

[1]: https://github.com/vshaxe/vshaxe-debugadapter
[2]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/42143768/vs-code-give-me-this-error-unable-to-open-unknown-source-file-not-found-un

EXTRA INFO:
At first I thought it was something to do with the fact that I had git running with VS but then I disabled it and my internet is still virtually unusable when running VS Code, the second I turn it off everything runs perfectly fine again.

data.title: C source build task output wrapped when using the same terminal more than once
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- Extensions: C/C++ 0.10.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create buggy C source to force compiler warning/error messages. 
2. Use **VS Build Tools 2017 RC** and the following tasks.json file:
```json
{
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "echoCommand": true,
  "_runner": "terminal",
    "tasks": [
      {
      "taskName": "cl",
      "command": "cl.exe ${file}",
      "isShellCommand": true,
      "isBackground": false,
      "problemMatcher": "$msCompile",
      "isBuildCommand": true,
      "showOutput": "always"
      }
    ]
}
```
3. Build the source once. Compiler warnings are displayed correctly in one long line.
4. Without closing the terminal, build the source once again. Compiler warnings are now wrapped at column 87.
5. If you close the terminal and recompile, output will be fine again.

[https://youtu.be/8-Wmb-8LyRg](https://youtu.be/8-Wmb-8LyRg)
